Patch Set 15:

There is a bit of a chicken and the egg problem going on in the docs.  It mentions the ability to provision an instance with an IP or use AddNic with a specific ip to explain what `reserved` is.

The docs also mention #UpdateNetworkIP which isn't out there yet.

Whats the best way to handle this?

Patch Set 15: CI-Testing+1

"make check" passed ok

Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1

> There is a bit of a chicken and the egg problem going on in the
 > docs.  It mentions the ability to provision an instance with an IP
 > or use AddNic with a specific ip to explain what `reserved` is.
 > 
 > The docs also mention #UpdateNetworkIP which isn't out there yet.
 > 
 > Whats the best way to handle this?

Either scale back and say "reserved" is for future expansion, OR explain that #UpdateNetworkIP and provision-with-IP are coming soon.  I prefer the latter.

Otherwise, ship it.

Change has been successfully merged by Michael Zeller
Is this so you can build on MacOS?
Yeah, Trent gave me this patch.
Just a generic question:  Does it matter which of server.{head,get} appears first?  Or is it just that fabrics have it one way, and non-fabrics have it the other?
Order shouldn't matter, but it looks like a style choice for cloudapi.  I will update and swap their order.

nit: Lowercase "p" here please for thisStyleNaming (as is done in listNetworkIps below).

FWIW, my pref would be to do that for the API endpoint names -- GetNetworkIp, ListNetworkIps -- but I understand if we'd want to somewhat match the naming on NAPI there and for the unfortunate existing "GetFabricVLAN" et al (instead of "GetFabricVlan"). :)
I have no real opinion on this.  I can go with lowercase "p" everywhere.

I actually like that NAPI use of all-caps where appropriate (case-sensitive grep/searching should find "IP" and "VLAN"), and prefer that.  But I'm a newbie in this space, so weight my opinion appropriately.

Dan, my (personal, I don't have a veto here :) objection is that some terms end up being special (IP, VLAN) and some not (Nic, Http, Api). That leads to inconsistent application of the naming guidelines, in my experience. For example, sdc-napi.git has these styles:

```
function ipProvisionable    # lowercase if start of name
function getIPKey           # uppercase start of next word
function addIPtoNic         # lowercase start of next word
function initIPbucket       
function nextGapIPsOnNetwork
function nextIPonNetwork
```

If we_were_using_this_style, I think we'd just put "ip" lowercase all the time and not have the debate.

Also, which names are special enough to be special?

Personally, for me, the idea of having certain acronyms be special enough to not following the camelCasing rule was long ago when I had an HTTPRESTAPI class (instead of HttpRestApi). :)
Prefer: assert.object(ip, 'ip');
Done
What is this about? The NAPI docs don't mention "belongs_to_type='other'" that I see: https://mo.joyent.com/docs/napi/master/#ips

You're right its not in the docs.  https://github.com/joyent/sdc-napi/blob/master/lib/models/ip/common.js#L172

I can put a cr in to add it to the napi docs.
https://cr.joyent.us/#/c/2731
napi.listIPs in sdc-clients doesn't handle paging. It should be updated to do so. Can you open a separate ticket for this? As soon as there are >1000 matching IPs, this endpoint will be broken.
I have TOOLS-1867 open for this.  I was trying to wait for vasync.whilst to go in before doing the work.  Since the rest of sdc-clients is a mix between async.js and home grown solutions.

NAPI docs don't show ListIPs taking an "owner_uuid" param. Can you open a ticket to fix that, please?

It looks like this is the schema used for allowed params to that NAPI endpoint: https://github.com/joyent/sdc-napi/blob/1a65a342fc2b2069a6c5524ac346d6d09bc084e4/lib/models/ip/index.js#L57-L69
Yeah I added that recently in NAPI-433.  I can open a ticket to add that to the docs as well.
https://cr.joyent.us/#/c/2731
Done

This can be rewritten as:

ips = ips.map(translateIP);
Done
Name this function.
Dumb question:  What's the threshold for naming an inlined passed function?  There are similar no-named functions above, but they're shorter.

There's no policy that I'm aware of. When in doubt, name it. Naming every function is fine too.

Length plays a role, because that tends to be correlated with complexity. More stuff to go wrong.
Okay.  Asked because of the aforementioned small, but no-named, inline functions-as-parameters.
Q: To be clear, we *do* want to allow account 'bob' to list and get the IP owned by account 'alice' on a private network for which both alice and bob are owners?

Yea we discussed that on https://github.com/joyent/rfd/issues/49
If your uuid is a member of owner_uuids you should be able to list/modify those IPs.
I don't think these need to be put on the API for those calling the 7.3.0 API version. So just `['8.0.0']` would do.
Done

Correct me if I'm wrong, but I think `validateNetwork` doesn't consider `vlan_id`, so it doesn't restrict `:id` to networks on that VLAN, in that fabric. In other words, I'd be able to:

/trent.mick/fabrics/default/vlans/42/networks/$publicNetworkUuid

I think this processing needs to copy some of the logic in getFabricNetwork.
Good catch, oversight on my end.  Will get a fix in for this.
Discussed this in chat.  Its a cleaner API to leave these out and have users go through the proper endpoints.
Can you also test if either .1 or .254 (commonly used for routers) can be reserved?  Silly, but kinda important.
Not a fan of this. I'd rather we used a fixed signature and updated all the other call sites to use {}.
Didn't give this function a name, per a prior request.  Please do so?
Maybe this can be replaced with a find() instead? And eliminate the [] and length calls below?
Done
Personally, I'd call this networkUuid. More descriptive than _n.
Done
typo
Done
Do non-public IPs not have owner_uuid set? It might be simpler to always filter by owner_uuid?
A reserved IP that is not provisioned to an instance does not have the owner_uuid set.
Again, if owner_uuid is always set, maybe always apply this check, not just if !net.owner_uuids?
Like above, only we don't care about returning reserved IPs here.  We explicitly want to only return IPs owned by the user.

This is perfectly fine, but other test files use a slightly different tack:

In test('setup') there should be a "OTHER = clients.other;" line, and then later on in the tests you can use "OTHER.account.uuid". The consistency would help with grepping in the future.

But this is super nitpicky. Up to you.
Ummm, changing caps here, but not changing them in the function name?  I'm confused...
I did it to match line 717.  The actual handler name.
I think a block comment on this function with the notes on what to expose and the reasons for it (see my comment below on "updated rules") would be helpful.
Done
literally 'adminUuid' here, I think.
Done

The updated rules for ipFromNapiIp (aka `translateIp`) are (from my read of the discussion GH issue):

- `ip`: always show

- `reserved`: always show

- `owner_uuid`: show if defined on the NAPI IP object, and if it is NOT
  $adminUuid

- `belongs_to_type` & `belongs_to_uuid`: Only show if:
    - you are the owner (bias to not showing the other accounts' VMs for now); and
    - `belongs_to_type==="zone"` (we felt that showing belongs_to_type=server
      would probably be fine, but it is rare -- only admin and maybe poseidon
      accounts -- and it is easier to add it later if needed rather than remove
      it later if it is a problem).

Currently `translateIp` here (a) doesn't expose `belongs_to_type` and (b) I think the conditions are wrong for `belongs_to_uuid` for two accounts with IPs on the same shared network.

(a) I thought we agreed that we wouldn't expose `belongs_to_type` at all at this point since it should always be zone. That we would later add it to the api if/when we extended napi to be more descriptive.  Either way if you think we should send it along I can push another change.

(b) good catch.  Fixing.
Looks like this will fit on one 80 char line.
Done

or if owner is 'admin'. Perhaps just drop this so we don't repeat the code logic? Sorry if I'm asking for over-documenting here.

The CloudAPI API docs will explain the intended meaning of each field. If anything, the docs here could inform the maintainer about some of the cases where we said "yes, we could expose this, but we decided not to because we don't need it now and could add it later if needed".
Done
nit: Perhaps "accountUuid" to not create a possible confusion with the term "user" sometimes used for RBAC v1 subusers?
Done
nit: s/valid/validate/
Done
Done

Given that there is a limitation that net pools aren't supported here (PUBAPI-1441), but that CloudAPI doesn't make it easy for users to distinguish pool from network, it would be good to briefly discuss the limitation. Perhaps pointing out that while not every ID from `triton networks` will be usable here, every "network_uuid/network" from NICs and instances (machines) will be usable here.
Done
Also when calling UpdateNics (or AddNic or whatever it is called :) right? If so perhaps clarify that.
I think we should leave mention of UpdateNic / CreateMachine / AddNic out of the docs for now until those endpoints are implemented?
Sure.
Perhaps not tabs in here.
Done
You are perhaps waiting until node-triton is updated to show client examples?
I will show examples of both.
Perhaps not tabs in here.
Done

Perhaps add networkUuid to this. Tho FWIW, the job of logging the response body should (for all cloudapi endpoints) be left to the "audit" logger. That can (it does for sdc-docker at least) have guards for accidentally logging huge payloads, etc.  Anyway, fine to have this here. I'm rambling. :)
Oops look like vim s/\t/ /g didnt do a good job.  Theres other characters in here.  Ill push a change.
This actually comes back as a JSON array right?

pipe to  json -ag got me here.  
Will fix

This name is a little misleading given that it is being used for "can we list IPs on this network" things.  Perhaps something like validateNetworkForIps  or something (that name still is kinda lame :).
Done

Nit: it would be really nice to include the specific net pool UUID in this error message. Also to be more specific about what about net pools isn't support... e.g. if a user sees this error message from code that uses node-triton as a lib so it isn't obvious what endpoint was involved. E.g.

    ('cannot get IPs in a network pool: %s', net.uuid)
Done
